Flood waters may have receded through much of the Midwest, but not from Spring Green, Wisconsin - at least not enough.
In that town the water is not receding quickly enough and that could cause a problem with federal aid.
FEMA has pledged to help homeowners displaced by the floods, but it will not send in inspectors until all the water is gone.
Wisconsin Public Radio's Brian Bull reports.
Waist-deep water covers much of Spring Green's farmlands and neighborhoods, as well as its cemetery and motel.
(Soundbite of motor running)
Near a main intersection, a large diesel-powered pump roars away as cars slosh through the frothy water.
(Soundbite of water running)
Town chairman Benny Stenner says the pump is slowly draining water from what locals call The Lake, a space that sprawls 300 acres under an estimated 150 million gallons of water.
The pump's positioned over the town's only sewer connecting with the Wisconsin River two miles away.
It began pumping in June, a month that brought 15 inches of rain over a five-day period.
Friday the 13th we started it up and we've been pumping ever since, 24 hours a day since then, and that's our only exit for water right now.
The pump removes a million gallons of water daily, but it's not nearly enough.
It's a mere drop out of the buckets.
Thanks to an unusually high water table and the region's flat prairie, Spring Green's 1,400 residents are dealing with a flood that simply won't subside.
You can smell the smell as soon as you walk in here.
People like Kevin Wilkins, whose basement is under five feet of stagnant, gray water.
Everything down there is destroyed - furnace, a hot water heater, a lot of family heirlooms, photo albums and clothing of our kids when they were young.
But until inspectors can actually see the furnace, FEMA inspectors aren't going to Wilkins basement anytime soon.
FEMA coordinator Dolph Diemont recent explained the situation at a packed town hall meeting.
We have over a half million dollars in this Spring Green community already through checks distributed for homes that are not under water.
But we're in a situation where we send an inspector out, they have a checklist and they have to say the furnace, there's structural damage, the washer and dryer is bad.
They literally can't do an inspection until they can get into the home.
Even in Katrina, no homes were under water this long.
Diemont said he could understand people's frustration.
FEMA and state leaders say they're trying to work out an assessment process unique to this town, but there's no timeline.
Meanwhile, a coalition of local farmers and homeowners is pushing their own solution - build drainage ditches under the town's main street.
Farmer Jeff Sprecher, who's lost close to 150 acres and some cattle to the flood waters, says the plan is simple.
Highway 14 is a dike.
It will not let the water cross.
I talked to several engineers that could put culverts under the highway.
Basically, poke a hole in and not even shut traffic down.
And we could have this water moved out in a short time, instead of five years from now.
